I'm closing this.

Hopefully we can move to requests in the near future and we don't need this code anymore.
Thank you. I have a local PowerDNS server here, so I executed the raw REST commands using curl, and then I pasted the JSON output from curl into the .json fixtures.

Thanks for the PR.

I agree with you and if nothing else, we should provide a way (module level setting / environment variable) to disable lxml in case user for whatever reason doesn't want to use it.

And yeah, as far as Python 3 + lxml goes, I haven't done much testing of that combination.

Would you be OK with something like that to begin with?

To begin with, I will merge https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/763 into trunk and then we can decide how to proceed.

First step would probably be allowing user to disable lxml.

As far as "Unfortunately lxml often sneaks its way into real-world virtual environments via dependencies such as premailer so removing it entirely from a solution as a workaround would often be difficult to do in practice." comment goes - usually the best thing to do is to isolate different applications using virtual environments and have a virtual environment per application (this way there won't be a any dependency clashes, that's usually a best practice).

I know that's not always possible that's why I'm fine with adding a way to disable lxml.

Sorry, didn't want to close this PR, merge commit automatically closed it.

In any case, let's continue discussion on this problem in this issue / thread :)

One option would also be to make it opt-in instead of opt-out by default.

What do others think?
Merged, thanks.
thanks @bonifaido

My 2c is having an option would be an acceptable short term fix, especially if there's a strong desire to get `v1.0.0` shipped. Some considerations:
- Security https://bitbucket.org/tiran/defusedxml#rst-header-python-xml-libraries
- Speed http://lxml.de/performance.html
Came up in some Googling https://github.com/ministryofjustice/salt-cloud-provider-vcloud/issues/7

Thanks a lot.

It would be great if you can add some test case for this. I know this was causing issues under Python 3 and that's why we added that code.

Thanks for additional clarification, I didn't know it was causing issues in Salt as well.

In this case I think it's reasonable to make it opt-in by default (aka disabling it by default).

I will merge this into trunk so at least part of the code base is covered by pylint (right now that is `libcloud/{common,dns}`).

pylint also indicated some bigger underlying issues with wrong usage of multiple inheritance, etc. but I decided to only fix small things and added pragmas to ignore those other parts (I don't want to break more code).

Thanks @kami going to close this as copying the change into the relevant `MockResponse` classes reveals this won't work with JSON responses, e.g. 
`json.loads(b'hi')` => TypeError: the JSON object must be str, not 'bytes'

Hey @teemuvesula thanks for the contribution  I think I know what happened. There are 3 types of accounts in godaddy API. I tested on my account, which is the type that apparently doesn't require that header. Which type of account are you using? I'm going to pull this fork and check it locally with my API keys as well because I think the addition of the header is optional but if you include it I'm not sure if they ignore it. 
https://developer.godaddy.com/getstarted

I run into this issue with the Azure driver and python 2.7.9-11. I can confirm this fixes the issue for me.

Calling list_images() from the Azure driver will reproduce the original issue

@tonybaloney - Yes, it is optional at GoDaddy API, but if the header exists, then it has to be valid. Unfortunately in at the current code the LibCloud tries to send it always - no matter what the value is. 

I was thinking that the X-Shopper-Id should be totally optional, but it would need more code changes. Also at that point the constructor of GoDaddyDNSDriver should be changed so that whole shopper_id is optional. Unfortunately that would break the whole backward compatibility. I think that it's bad idea.

ok so the change should just include a small `if self.shopper_id is not None:` around 
add_default_headers line for adding the header.
Ok - now that change is done also.
Changes look great.
:+1: merging
hi @pzrq I really appreciate you sticking with this thanks for the contribution

- @erjohnso
erm. why are you printing an empty string in the first place @wrigri ?
LGTM

@tonybaloney The reason for this print is that right above we are calling a 'sys.stdout.write()' with only a CR (no LF) to display output from the instances in a loop (continually overwriting the line). The print makes sure that we get a final line feed in there so that the next output properly shows up on the next line (instead of the same one).

@teemuvesala Yeah, I agree.

I recently also enabled pylint so this should also help with catching at least part of the similar issues in the future.

thanks @bonifaido for the contribution, I've made some comments on the conventions at the project that just need implementing, also it would be great to get docstrings and also a doc page on the driver, explain how the authentication mechanism works.
We also ask for tests and mock responses to be included for new drivers as well as an ICLA to be signed (if you haven't already).
cc @erjohnso
LGTM @wrigri, could you squash commits please?

Commits squashed.

BTW, apparently github has a new feature as of this month that allows commits to be automatically squashed at merge time: https://github.com/blog/2141-squash-your-commits
typo in commit f5537811d97a7b58a1222a2f43dfccfa6add3bc6 message. Should've marked #779 as closed.

@tonybaloney I reviewed the PUT case. The Libcloud code required one minor fix to handle the different behaviour related to ETags in the Amazon S3 and Ceph RGW implementations. Ceph RGW is not shipping ETag headers in this case so the code needs to handle the case where ETags don't exist. BTW, Ceph RGW was not handling the case for unsigned payloads in the PUT method so I pushed this support in Ceph and it is upstream now with Jewel 10.2.0 The PUT method is working now. Tests are passing. The header dumps for Amazon S3 and Ceph RGW using the new patch follow... 
Amazon S3
---------

@kami updated! I tested the 'last connectionCls wins' issue with the following code: 
$ cat ex.py  
#!/usr/bin/env python
from libcloud.storage.types import Provider, ContainerDoesNotExistError
from libcloud.storage.providers import get_driver
import libcloud
container_name = 'container-example'
object_name = 'object-example'
cls = get_driver(Provider.S3_RGW_OUTSCALE)
driver1 = cls('id', 'secret', region='eu-west-1', secure=False, signature_version='4')
driver2 = cls('id', 'secret', region='us-east-2', secure=False, signature_version='2')
print "driver1.connectionCls = %s" % (driver1.connectionCls)
print "driver1.connectionCls.host = %s" %( driver1.connectionCls.host)
print "driver2.connectionCls = %s" % (driver2.connectionCls)
print "driver2.connectionCls.host = %s" %( driver2.connectionCls.host)
$ ./ex.py 
driver1.connectionCls = <class 'libcloud.storage.drivers.s3.S3RGWOutscaleConnectionAWS4'>
driver1.connectionCls.host = osu.eu-west-1.outscale.com
driver2.connectionCls = <class 'libcloud.storage.drivers.s3.S3RGWOutscaleConnectionAWS2'>
driver2.connectionCls.host = osu.us-east-2.outscale.com

@kami would it be possible merging this PR as it is and then iterating over this pylint error if needed?

Libcloud is using the PUT + UNSIGNED-PAYLOAD + Auth header combination to sign uploads via S3. This combo is not available in the Ceph RGW's s3-tests in this moment, so having this RGW driver in place would be useful to add the Libcloud coverage in Ceph. This way everybody (s3-tests, developers and users) could use the same upstream code without modifications.

The Libcloud support in Ceph (PUT + UNSIGNED-PAYLOAD + Auth header) was upstream several weeks ago. I commented on this issue. It is available at:

https://github.com/ceph/ceph/pull/8601

Thanks!

Thanks for the contribution! I will look into it shorty.

In the mean time, would it be possible to add some tests for this new authentication method?

> @kami I updated the PR to adjust the hierarchy although pylint is expected to fail with this new update. With this PR I am suggesting the following hierarchy: S3RGWOutscaleStorageDriver -> S3RGWStorageDriver -> S3StorageDriver

@jmunhoz I think the correct class-hierarchy should be  S3StorageDriver -> S3RGWStorageDriver -> S3RGWOutscaleStorageDriver.

The reason for that is that S3 is the generic S3 implementation and other S3 based providers should inherit from it (and not vice-versa).

If needed, we could also refactor base S3 functionality into BaseS3Driver and then have the following class hierarchy - BaseS3Driver -> S3Driver, BaseS3Driver -> S3RGWStorageDriver, S3RGWStorageDriver -> S3RGWOutscaleStorageDriver (that's similar to what we do with EC2 driver right now).
Also, the lint issue is actually a very minor one, please see https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/786/files#r63909503.
@Kami I have added tests for the new authentication method.

I fixed the lint issue and went ahead and merged PR into trunk - thanks!

When you get a chance, please also submit a corresponding PR with tests.

Thanks for the contribution.

Can you please provide some more context on this change (since it's a pretty big one)?

Thanks for the contribution.

I will look into the pricing issue. Sadly Amazon doesn't have an official API for instance pricing so we resort on some (not so robust) price scrapping...

I thought they maybe removed support for those instance types in some regions, but it doesn't seem so. Pricing is still available on the pricing page, but not in the pricing javascript / JSON files.

I will update the code so it can also handle cases when pricing is not available.

@kami Thanks for taking care of this review. I was working on your review comments the last hours but I was not fast enough to update the PR before merging and closing this PR.

I think I have a PR addressing your previous comments now. It has a better design and it is not forced by the kwargs issue.

I reviewed the class-hierarchy stuff and I think we are on the same page. I was using UML notation (maybe not the best choice to communicate my idea in plain text, sorry!) with the following meaning subclass -> superclass. As mentioned I think we are on the same page. The code follows this class hierarchy.

By the way,  I think the lint fix could be breaking the driver cause it will call on the parent constructor without the signature_version parameter (it was pop'ed in the subclass) so the parent will set the default signature (v2). The previous code was jumping over the parent's constructor. It was the reason to lint complaining.

As commented, I will test the link fix and I will open a new PR to fix it if needed together with the improvements suggested by you on the previous revision.

Made the changes above and merged your PR into trunk.

Thanks!
@jmunhoz Sounds good & thanks :)

The change involves mainly the creation and deletion process of a record.

If you have a record "foo.bar.com A 127.0.0.1" and you do want to add "foo.bar.com A 10.0.0.1" the method create_record() fails, because does not consider that a record with the same id could be already present, A:foo in this case.

Insted if you already have two record with the same id (A:foo) and you do want to delete one, the method delete_record() fails because does not check _others_records, so it does not correctly format the field data in batch command.

Finally ex_delete_all_records fails because first it creates a delete command for each record, while amazon groups records by id, and secondly the command was not correcly formatted because it does not consider _others_record

The patch modifies _post_changeset in order to correctly consider _other_records

The tests work successfully, but it does not check that cases and in the real world  without the patch they fail.
@kami I opened a new PR https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/792 It fixes the default signature issue.

@jmunhoz Thanks!

@jetbird Did you push your latest changes?

Since I don't see any new commits (license header is still missing, etc.).

Thanks.

I've added some additional asserts (084ce3cf7eaeeb4bd6bb0b5472b9f75ca59ec6cd) and merged changes into trunk. I believe there is still a bug with they way the host is handled though:

``` python
       ....
        self.driver_v2 = self.driver_type(*self.driver_args,
                                          signature_version='2',
                                          host='host1')
        self.driver_v4 = self.driver_type(*self.driver_args,
                                          signature_version='4',
                                          host='host2')

        print self.driver_v2.connectionCls.host
        print self.driver_v4.connectionCls.host
```

And when running it:

``` bash
osu.eu-west-2.outscale.com
osu.eu-west-2.outscale.com
```

As you can see, the host argument is ignored. That's probably because when `connectionCls` is instantiated, the `host` argument you set in the driver class constructor is overridden - as mentioned before, I recommend you to use `_ex_connection_class_kwargs` method. Overriding class variables is usually not a good idea, because it results in bugs and issues like that.

It would be great if you can look into it and also add corresponding tests (I didn't include those tests in the commit so it would cause the build to fail). When working on a fix, you can start with a failing test case :)
